questions.text: What is the composition of permutit which is used for the base exchange process to remove hardness of water?
questions.solution:
Permutit is a complex chemical compound made of sodium, aluminium and silica. It is used to remove hardness of water by base exchange process. 

Permutit has the property of ion exchange and removes calcium and magnesium from water. It removes both permanent and temporary hardness.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: You are conducting a study to determine the mean height of children visiting the local PHC. Which type of statistical study is being done here?
questions.solution:
A study to determine the mean height of children is an example of a descriptive statistical study.

Descriptive statistics are the statistical methods that merely organize, describe or summarize the actual data available. For example, a study determining the mean blood pressure of patients visiting a PHC on a single day.

Analytical statistics are the second major category of epidemiological studies, after descriptive statistics. The objective of an analytical study is to test the hypothesis.

An observational study is an empiric investigation in which the objective is to establish a relationship between cause and effect. It falls under the category of analytical statistics.

It is performed when controlled experimentation cannot be feasibly used to determine a hypothesis. For example, in the case of cigarette smoking causing lung cancer, it would be unethical and not feasible to conduct a controlled experiment. So, an observational study is preferred.

Inferential statistics involve inductive reasoning i.e., generalizing observations to a population after having observed only a sample. An example of such a study would be a study determining the expected success rate of vasectomy 

Theoretical statistics is a mathematical approach to describe something, predict events, or analyze the relationship between things. Some of the concepts of theoretical statistics are mean, median, mode, standard deviation and correlation.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide it into equal groups.

  • They are also referred to as fractiles.
  • Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.
  • The median is also considered a quantile as it divides a distribution into two equal parts. The median is also the same as the 50th percentile and second quartile.

Types of quantiles:

  1. Tertiles divide a distribution into 3 equal groups
  2. Quartiles divide it into 4 equal parts or quarters
  3. Quintiles divide a distribution into 5 equal groups
  4. Deciles divide a distribution into 10 equal parts
  5. Vigintiles divide it into 20 equal groups
  6. Centiles:
  • They are also called percentiles and are commonly used, especially for ranking marks in an exam.
  • They divide a distribution into 100 equal parts. Here, the median is the same as the 50th percentile.
  • The formula to arrive at the rank order of a value is R = P/100 x (n + 1), where R is the rank of the desired observation, P is the percentile desired and n is the number of variables in the data.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Six’s thermometer.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A young girl who is 1 month pregnant is concerned about a chest X-ray that she had taken 3 weeks back. What is the dose of radiation below which deterministic effects on the fetus are not seen?
questions.solution:
Deterministic effects on the fetus are not seen below 5 rads or 50 mSv of radiation.

Dose limits of radiation exposure are:

  • Occupational exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 20 mSv/year averaged over 5 consecutive years / 30 mSv in a year.
  • General public exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 1 mSv/year
  • Occupational exposure for pregnant staff - Effective dose to the fetus should not exceed 1mSv/year (same as the general public).

For pregnant patients who require diagnostics with exposure to ionising radiation, the radiation protection principles are followed:

  • The exposure should be justified
  • The dose should be as low as reasonably achievable (ALARA principle)
  • The dose limit is not particularly specified as it involves a single time exposure to diagnostic radiation. Usually, the effective dose to the fetus is <1msv and deterministic effects to the fetus are not seen below 50 mSv (5 Rad).

questions.text: The value of one parameter can be estimated from another related parameter by:
questions.solution:
The value of one parameter can be estimated from another related parameter by using regression techniques.

Related Pearl: Regression

When two variables are correlated, the value of one of the variables can be predicted from the value of the other using regression techniques.

  • Independent variable: The variable from which the other variable is calculated.
  • Dependent variable: The variable for which the value is calculated.

Types of regression:

1. Simple linear regression

  • In this, the value of one variable (y) is used to predict the value of another variable (x).
  • The regression equation is used for this purpose. It gives a straight-line relationship between the two variables.
  • It is given by the equation y = a + bx, where, a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
  • The intercept constant is the point where the Y-axis is intercepted by the regression line. 

 2. Multiple linear regression

  • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
  • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.

 3. Logistic regression

  •  In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease)
  • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly. Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
  • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variable y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.

questions.text: Which of the following carriers shed the organism for indefinite periods?
questions.solution:
Chronic carriers are those who shed or excrete the organism for indefinite periods.

Carriers are classified into chronic carriers and temporary carriers based on the duration.

Organisms may be shed continuously or intermittently in chronic carriers. The duration of the carrier state also depends on the disease. Chronic carrier state is seen in typhoid, hepatitis B, gonorrhea, malaria, etc. 

Temporary carriers are classified into:

  • Incubatory carriers - Those that shed the organism during the incubation period of the disease, especially during the later parts of it. It is seen in measles, mumps, polio, etc.
  • Healthy carriers - Those who suffer from subclinical infections and develop a carrier state without developing the overt disease. It is seen in polio, meningococcal meningitis, cholera, diphtheria, etc.
  • Convalescent carriers - Those that shed the organism during recovery or convalescence. It is seen in typhoid.

Paradoxical carrier refers to a carrier who acquires the pathogen from another carrier.

Note: Pseudo-carriers are carriers of avirulent organisms.

questions.text: What does evidence-based medicine refer to?

choices.text: Use of experiments to prove the cause of a disease
Use of clinical trials to prove safety of drugs
Use of research findings for taking decisions about patient care
Use of behavioral modification to prevent disease

questions.solution:
Evidence-based medicine (EBM) refers to the use of modern research findings to guide decision-making about the treatment of individual patients.

EBM integrates clinical experience and patient values with the best available research information. Research and studies are given high importance in EBM, while opinions and conventional wisdom of experts are not taken into consideration in the practice of EBM.

 David Sackett is called the Father of EBM.

Related Pearl: Evidence Pyramid in Research

The evidence pyramid gives the hierarchy or ranking of evidence from different types of methods used in research.

Animal research ranks the lowest, while meta-analysis ranks the highest and gives the best evidence.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about probability is true? (Probability of event occurring is p)
  1. p=1 means absolute certainty of event occurring
  2. p can be positive or negative
  3. The addition rule can be used to calculate probability 
  4. The probability of the event not occurring (q ) = p + 1
  5. The multiplication rule can be used to calculate probability
questions.solution:
If the probability of an event occurring is 1, it means there is an absolute certainty that the event will occur.

The addition rule and multiplication rule can be used to calculate the probability of an event. The addition rule is used to calculate the combined probability of the occurrence of two or more mutually exclusive events. The multiplication rule is used to calculate the combined probability of two or more statistically independent events occurring together.

Probability values range from 0 (no probability) to 1 (absolute certainty). So negative value of p is not possible.

Since p is the probability of an event occurring and q is the probability of the event not occurring,

q = 1 - p

Related Pearl: Probability

  • Expressed as a decimal fraction never as a percentage. Denoted by p
  • Must lie between 0 (zero probability) and 1 (absolute certainty).
  • Probability of an event cannot be negative.
  • The probability of an event not occurring (q) is q= 1-p

Rule

Description

Example

The Addition Rule

(p) of any one of several particular events occurring = the sum of their individual probabilities, provided the events cannot both happen and are mutually exclusive.

Probability of picking a heart card from a deck is 0.25 and that of picking a club is 0.25. Thus the p (hearts or clubs) is 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.50.

The Multiplication Rule

(p) of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is = product of their individual probabilities.

If the lifetime probability of a person developing a lung neoplasm is 0.25 and the life time probability of developing dementia is 0.01, then the p (lung neoplasm and dementia) is 0.25 x 0.01 = 0.0025.

The Binomial Distribution

 

(p) of the occurrence of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events.

The events for which binomial distribution is used have only two outcomes like yes or no, tall or short, male or female, etc.

 

Widely used in genetic counseling.

questions.text: You are conducting a cohort study in a group of headload workers to identify the risk factors for developing low back pain in future. This type of study falls under which of the following?

    • Field trials

  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:

    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: In which of the following processes is binomial distribution widely used?
questions.solution:
Binomial distribution is widely used in genetic counseling.

Binomial distribution helps determine the probability of occurance of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events. In a binomial distribution, there are only two possible events like Yes/No or Male/Female or Alive/Dead. The results of the distribution gives the probabilities of obtaining an exact number of successes in a series of independent trials.

For example, the inheritence of cystic fibrosis follows a binomial distribution. There are:

a. Two possible events - inheriting the disease/ not inheriting it

b. Events are mutually exclusive - one person cannot both have the disease and not have it

c. Independent possibilities - if one child has inherited it, this will not affect if the other child will inherit it.

The physician using this technique can explain to the patients the probabilities of their children suffering from the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about rapid sand filters?

choices.text: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity or pressure type

questions.solution:
Frequent washing of the filter bed is required in rapid sand filters. This is done by backwashing.

Related Pearl: Rapid Sand Filters

  • They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large scale purification of water.
  • The two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).
  • Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:
    • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum.
    • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
    • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminium hydroxide.
    • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculent along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place.
    • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
      • Filter beds: The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 metre and has graded gravel below it.
      • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer which adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.
      • Backwashing is done by reversing the flow of water through the sand bed. It dislodges the impurities and cleans the bed. Skilled labor is needed for this purpose.
    • Advantages of rapid sand filter:
      • Rapid sand filter does not need storage of water before it is treated.
      • It occupies less space when compared to slow sand filters.
      • Filtration is much more rapid than slow sand filters.
      • It is easy to wash and clean.
      • There is more flexibility in its operation.

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

The given image is of a cyclops or water flea. It is the vector for guinea worm disease or dracunculiasis and fish tapeworm infection.

Humans are infected with these diseases by drinking water that contains cyclops. Its average life span is 3 months. 

Physical methods like straining and boiling of water can ensure the killing of this organism. Chemicals that can be used to control cyclops are chlorine, lime, and abate. Biological methods include Gambusia fish and barbel fish.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of fever and malaise. He also complains of an itchy rash which first appeared on the trunk as shown below. When is this disease the most contagious?

choices.text: 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash
7 days before to 7 days after the onset of rash
4 days before to 4 days after the onset of rash

questions.solution:
The rash (different stages at one time) in the image and the clinical history are suggestive of chickenpox. The period of communicability for chickenpox is 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash.
